text:
Welcome to How To Cook That I'm Ann Reardon
and today we are making a spinning BB-8 cake.

My boys are all Star Wars fans and they of
course went to the midnight screening of Star

Wars 7 when it was released except for the
youngest one because he would have been alseep.

So I thought I'd better make BB-8 to add to
the Star Wars collection.

So far we have a Millenium Falcon cake and
a Chewbacca made from chocolate bars and now
the spinning BB-8.

To make this cake you will need a hemisphere
tin, put that on a bowl to stop it tipping
over.
And small bowl for the head.

Now we want our cake to come right to the
top so we can level it.
But we don't want it to overflow.

So put a sheet of baking paper around the
edge and I have just stapled that into place.
And do the same on the little bowl too.

Make a batch of 1 and a half times my chocolate
rich cake recipe and pour it nearly to the
top of each tin.

I'll put all the recipe quantities on the
HowToCookThat.net website in grams and ounces

and cups and there is a video for this cake
recipe too, I'll put the links below.

Bake them in the oven and I like to have an
empty tray on the top shelf to stop the bigger

one from burning on top before it's cooked
all the way through.

Once they are baked and cooled level off the
top just using the top of the tin as your
guideline there.

And for the body use a small amount of buttercream
to attach it to a cake board and then put
it on a bowl to make it easier to work with.

Cover the whole thing in a layer of buttercream
Then I like to use a sheet of thin plastic
or acetate just to smooth off the frosting.
And this is the easiest way with rounded cakes.
Place that in the fridge.

And then for the head cut about 1/3 off it
so that it will sit upright.

Then place it next to the round tin so that
you can see where to cut.

Just cut a bit form the underneath but not
too much or his head will fall over.

The head floats on top when he spins but we
do want it as close as possible.

Then cover that in buttercream just like we
did for the body.

Now roll out some white fondant and drape
it over the top of the body.

Lift and lower and lift and lower all the
way around the edge just to smooth out that
fondant.

And once you have it sitting nicely all the
way around just use a sharp knife to cut around
the base of the board.
Repeat that with the head as well.

For the head, roll out a thick layer of black
fondant and using a bowl the same size as
the one you baked it in cut a circle of black.

Then do that again but this time cutting a
circle of white and use your finger to smooth
out the edges.

Take some silver luster dust and dust around
the edges of the black.

Then gently lift up the head and place it
on the black.
Then lift that up and put it on the white.

So we end up with that silver strip around
the base.

Now using the template cut a thin strip of
orange and then cut little squares and rectangles
in the size shown.

Then put those pieces into place where they
go on the head.

Use the template to draw the indents around
the eye area.

Then add a little bit of water to the second
orange part and add a little bit of black,

use your knife to straighten it up, then a
little strip of white.

Take a piping tip and dip it in some black
gel food colour and then use that to make
a circle at the front.

Now if you don't have different size piping
tips just pull a pen apart and clean it, there
are heaps of circles in a pen.

If you want to you can also put some food
colour on a knife and go around the indents,

it really depends if you want to make your
BB8 to look brand new and shiny or you want
him to look dirty like he's been in the desert.

Add a strip of orange near the top of the
eye area on both sides.

Then use two circle cutters to cut a ring
of black and then dust that with silver luster
dust.

Add that to the top of his little head and
then make indents around it, these go bigger
then smaller, bigger then smaller.
In the size shown cut a circle of black.
And then make a hole in the middle of that.
And add that ring to the front.

Then cut a circle of black and add that to
the other section there.

Now roll a thin cylinder of white and this
is for his ariel and leave it to one side
to dry out.

Roll some orange thinly and rub a little oil
on top.

And then add the template to it, the oil just
stops the template from sticking.
Cut around it using a sharp knife.

And then take off the excess, leaving you
with the funny circle shape with the indents
going in, and you'll need four of these.

Use the main template to guide you where to
put them on the body, and just use a little
bit of water to make it stick.

Add them to the cake and reposition them as
you go, if you have heaps of time you can

freeze these pieces to make them easier to
put on.

Otherwise you can just put them on directly
like I have.

Cut all the silver pieces out of black fondant
again rolled fairly thin.

If you make them too thick it will bump the
head when the body is spinning around.

Brush those with silver luster dust so they
are all shiny.

Then carefully add them into place on BB8's
body.

Draw lines between the circles as shown on
the template and then we want to add the little
joiners.

Use a piping tip or part of a pen to make
circles and then use a smaller circle inside
each one of those.

And again you can do this with black food
colour too if you want.

Each orange bit needs a joiner too so put
that on each one of those.

Now take an MDF board and cover it in plastic
wrap and add a lazy susan upside down, that's

what they're called here in Australia I don't
know if that's what they're called in the
rest of the world.
I've added some fondant to level out the feet.
I got this one fairly cheaply online.

Spread the rest of the buttercream across
the bottom half of the board, smoothing it
over the lay susan so you can't see a lump.

Then process some biscuits or cookies depending
where you live in the world until they are
fine.

And you can do this in a plastic bag instead
and bash them with a rolling pin if you don't
have a processor.
And then spread that over the buttercream.

Add a strip of blue grey fondant to the top
of the board for the sky.

And what else you put in the background is
completely up to you, I am adding fence, you

can add other spaceships or happy birthday
or whatever you like.

Now to make BB-8 look like he's been in the
dusty desert grab some brown powdered food

colouring and using a dry brush dust it on
just around the joins and the orange.

Then add that into place making sure it is
exactly centred.

You can check that by placing your finger
at the top and giving it a gentle spin and
it shouldn't be bumping at any point.

Use a skewer to make a hole in the top of
the head and add his ariel.

I think he actually has two ariels but one
was broken until Rey fixed it and I can't
remember which one it was.

Add the head into place just above the body
and check it can spin past freely.

Then crush up some different coloured biscuits
and add them on the sand for BB8's shadow.

Roll a ball of black for his eye and cut it
in two, then take it outside and spray it
with the cake shine.
We do it outside so it doesn't cover the kitchen.

Bring them back in and then add them into
place on the head.

And BB-8 is ready to spin his way around the
dessert, isn't he cute.

chocolates and desserts, click here for the

recipe,
here for more Star Wars videos
and here for my YouTube channel
